title: Most picturesque hill towns [Photos]
text:
Wednesday, September 02, 2015 07:00 AM CDT Most picturesque hill towns Previous Next 
Volterra, Italy: This Tuscan hill town dates back to the Roman Age, though it got a modern lease on life after being featured in The Twilight Saga books as the hometown of the Volturi coven of vampires. (Shutterstock) 
Route of the White Hill Towns, Spain: The Andaluc√≠a region of Spain is the perfect place to road trip while visiting some of the prettiest hill towns in the world. From Nerja to Zahara to Grazalema, these hill towns -- collectively known as the Route of the White Hill Towns thanks to the white buildings in each -- offer a taste of authentic Spanish life. (Shutterstock) 
Assisi, Italy: Located in Italy's Umbria region, this hill town is famous as the place where St. Francis of Assisi was born. There are a number of churches and medieval castles in the city, which was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site. (Shutterstock) 
Cortona, Italy: In legends, this Tuscan hill town was thought to be founded by the son of Noah, who, 273 years after the flood, liked the height the hill offered and built a city at the location. Cortona is popular with tourists who flock here for its Renaissance architecture and medieval attractions. (Shutterstock) 
Darjeeling, India: This Indian hill town is the best known in the Darjeeling Himalayan hill region, famed as a tourist destination for its hill side location, architecture, tea and Darjeeling Himalayan Railway. (Shutterstock) 
Guanajuato, Mexico: Founded in 1548, this Mexican town rises from a valley, having been built into the surrounding hillsides. Many streets are too narrow for cars and the unique architecture of buildings and even staircases reflects its location on a hillside. (Shutterstock) 
Machu Picchu, Peru: This iconic hill town is also one of the best-known in the world, most recently having been voted one of the New7Wonders of the World. Machu Picchu was built by members of the Inca tribe and is the most recognizable symbol of their early civilization. (Shutterstock) 
Montepulciano, Italy: This medieval town, located on a limestone ridge, dates back as far at the third century. It is popular with tourists for its Renaissance architecture and attractions, as well as its car-free streets. (Shutterstock) 
San Gimignano, Italy: This Tuscan hill town is famed for its architecture and stunning, iconic white towers, which can reportedly be seen many kilometres away. The town was founded in the third century. (Shutterstock) 
Shimla, India: Often called "The Queen of Hills," this Indian hill town is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the Himachal Pradesh area. Located in the Himalayas, the town has a height of 2,205 metres above sea level. (Shutterstock) Article
